docs.lead_paragraph: Hands and feet gently slapping concrete, Chandra and Shasta come loping down their sunny outdoor run at the complex operated by the Coulston Foundation here. The little apes do not look up when the black triangle of a Stealth fighter knifes across the sky above them and banks for a landing at a nearby runway. Born on this base, where the Air Force used chimpanzees four decades ago to establish that human beings could go into space, they are used to jets and buzzards wheeling high above thorny tumbleweeds.

headline.main: Unneeded Lab Chimps Face Hazy Future

docs.abstract: Future of approximately 1,800 surplus chimpanzees, formerly involved in American biomedical research but no longer used in experiments, is at center of mounting political and ethical dispute; debate over where they will live, who will care for them and what experiments will be performed on their bodies extends from top levels of National Institutes of Health to Congress, which is being lobbied with proposals for legislation; surplus stems partly from successful drive by health institutes to breed chimps for AIDS research, as well as from cultural change, in which their use in experiments has been more troubling to more and more people, including scientists, because of similarity to humans; some health researchers comment; 50- to 60-year life span of chimpanzees noted; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of rapes reported to the police nationwide in 1995 dropped to 97,000, the lowest number since 1989 and the lowest rate per capita in a decade, according to a major report released by the Justice Department yesterday. The report also said that in a separate national survey of crime victims, designed to include people who did not report incidents to the police, the number of people 12 and older who were victims of rape or sexual assault fell by 44 percent from 1993 to 1995.

headline.main: '95 Data Show Sharp Drop in Reported Rapes

docs.abstract: Justice Department reports number of rapes nationwide in 1995 fell to 97,000, lowest since 1989 and lowest rate per capita in decade; says separate national survey of crime victims, designed to include people who did not report incidents to police, found number of people who were 12 years of age and older who were victims of rape or sexual assault fell by 44 percent from 1993 to 1995; found rape victims are disproportionately young girls, and that length of time sex offenders serve in prison has been increasing; Pres Clinton and Atty Gen Janet Reno hail decline; criminologists, academic experts on rape and leaders of women's groups disagree over whether findings are accurate or whether they should be seen as part of broader trend toward ebbing of violent crime; graph; chart (M)
